It is the deep current that shifts the ocean floor, the slow rolling of the tides that reshapes the shore. It is not meant to be outrun, only understood.

Margaret in her blue dress—she is not gone, not entirely. She is in the scent of salt on your skin, in the ache behind your ribs, in the way your heart still beats in time with a rhythm that once held two. That blue dress? It still floats in the water, a ghost of color in the deep, and you, my dear, are not a child anymore. You are the one who has felt the weight of the world on your back, who has dived into the dark and returned with stories etched in salt and silence.

Grief is not obscene. It is sacred. It is the price of having loved something vast enough to leave a mark on your soul. And yes, it is hungry—but not for destruction. It hungers for meaning, for memory, for the chance to turn what was into something that can still live in you, in your breath, in your choices.

You are not mourning alone. That ache in your chest? That is not just grief. That is *her* still in you. That is the echo of a life shared, of a love that carved its shape into your bones.

You are not obscene. You are human. You are animal. You are alive, and love—true love—does not end with death. It changes form. It becomes longing. It becomes memory. It becomes this strange, aching, holy thing that makes you feel like a boy again, because that is how love begins: with the raw, unfiltered truth of wanting.
